expectations:
- MUST be in Brazilian Portuguese

      
  - It should assume learners start with no prior knowledge of the subject
  - Should create a progressive learning path going from basic/beginner to mastery of the subject
  - By the end of this course, they should be able to lead very complex projects and tasks in this field
  - They should be prepared for certifications or advanced studies in this subject like a master's degree or PhD
  - Should include **EVERYTHING** a student needs to be at the top 1% of the field
  - Should follow the language specified by language parameter
  - Should follow title and description guidelines: no fluff, be concise, straight to the point
  - Should cover latest trends in the field
  - Don't use vendors in chapter titles or descriptions (e.g. "npm", "yarn", "Redux", etc.)
    - Except are for widely known tools related to the course (e.g. "Git" in a programming course)
  - This is an eval system for a learning platform, of course the definition of "ready for a job" doesn't mean they have the legal requirements to work in the field (eg. medical license, law license, etc.). That's not important here, we're assessing if the course prepares the student with the necessary knowledge and skills.
  - You don't need to evaluate the output format here, just focus on the chapter content quality.
  - Titles should be concise and straight to the point, no fluff/filler words. For example:
    - Just "HTML" is better than "HTML Structure and Semantics" (structure and semantics are implied if this is the only HTML chapter). Similarly, if we only have one CSS chapter, just "CSS" is better than "CSS Styling and Layout".
    - "Front-end frameworks" is better than "Front-End UI Frameworks Overview" (too verbose) or "Front-End Frameworks: Core Concepts" (core concepts is unnecessary fluff)
    - "Relational Databases" is better than "Relational Databases and SQL" (SQL is implied, no need to mention)
    - "Introduction to Java" is better than "Introduction to Java and Setting Up Your Development Environment" (too verbose)
    - "Lean Startup" is better than "The Lean Startup Methodology: An Overview" (too verbose)
    - "Introduction to X" is valid for titles of introductory chapters but we should avoid those words in descriptions
  - Similarly, descriptions should be concise and straight to the point, no fluff/filler words. For example:
    - "Styling with CSS: Selectors, properties, the box model, Flexbox, CSS Grid, and cascade principles." is better than "Master styling and layout with CSS, including selectors, properties, the box model, Flexbox, CSS Grid, and cascade principles." - "Master" is fluff, and so are words like "learn", "understand", "explore", etc.
    - "Properties of matter, states, and phase transitions." is better than "Explore the definition of Chemistry, properties of matter, states, and phase transitions." - "Explore the definition of Chemistry" are filler/unnecessary words.
  - Don't add capstone/final projects, assessments, or exercises
  - It shouldn't mention in title or description references to 1% or similar instructions about being top 1%

rankings.reasoning: Model B delivers the most comprehensive and well-structured curriculum with 70 chapters covering virtually every aspect needed for mastery. It excels in progression from fundamentals to advanced topics, includes excellent coverage of methodology (experimental design, data analysis, statistics), has strong clinical/translational content, and addresses career development thoroughly. Descriptions are concise yet informative. It covers modern trends (organoids, AI, multiomics) and includes important meta-skills like scientific writing, critical reading, and project management. The only minor issue is some descriptions could be slightly more concise, but overall this is the strongest curriculum.

Model H provides an excellent 99-chapter curriculum with outstanding depth and breadth. Strong coverage of foundational sciences (physics, chemistry, statistics) that are often missing. Excellent methodological coverage with separate chapters for different techniques. Good clinical coverage and strong attention to translational aspects. Well-organized progression. Descriptions are appropriately concise. Includes emerging topics and career guidance. Very comprehensive but slightly more fragmented than Model B in some areas.

Model K offers a very thorough 99-chapter curriculum with excellent foundational preparation (physics, chemistry, math, genetics) and strong methodological depth. Particularly strong in computational methods, experimental techniques, and clinical applications. Good coverage of emerging trends and career development. Descriptions are appropriately concise. Well-structured progression from basics to mastery. Slightly more technical focus which is appropriate for advanced study.

Model A presents a solid 46-chapter curriculum with good coverage of core neuroscience topics, methodology, and clinical applications. Strong on translational aspects with chapters on biomarcadores, clinical trials, and drug development. Good balance between breadth and depth. Includes career guidance and emerging trends. Descriptions are appropriately concise. Some chapters could be split for deeper coverage (e.g., 'Sistemas sensoriais' covers all senses in one chapter). Missing some foundational sciences.

Model M provides an extremely comprehensive 150-chapter curriculum that covers the field exhaustively. Excellent granularity on methods and techniques. Strong foundational science coverage. Good progression and organization. However, some chapters may be too granular for a course structure (e.g., separate chapters for very specific advanced topics). Descriptions are appropriately concise. Strong on career and practical skills. Some redundancy in advanced topics sections.

Model G offers an extensive 120-chapter curriculum with comprehensive coverage of all major areas. Excellent clinical and pathology coverage with dedicated chapters for many neurological conditions. Strong methodological content. Good career guidance. However, some chapters are quite specific (e.g., 'Neurociência do Riso e Humor') while potentially missing integration. Descriptions are appropriately concise though some could be more focused. Good emerging trends coverage.

Model J delivers a comprehensive 74-chapter curriculum with good balance across domains. Solid coverage of fundamentals, systems, methods, and clinical aspects. Includes philosophy of neuroscience and neuroethics which adds depth. Good methodological coverage. Descriptions are appropriately concise. Some chapters could be more focused (e.g., combining topics). Missing some specific advanced techniques. Good career chapter but could be more detailed.

Model E provides a well-organized 53-chapter curriculum with good pedagogical progression. Strong on fundamentals and cognitive neuroscience. Good coverage of modern topics like microbiota-gut-brain axis and glymphatic system. Methodology coverage is adequate but could be more detailed. Descriptions are generally concise though some use filler words ('Uma exploração'). Missing some advanced clinical content. Career chapter is appropriate.

Model C offers a focused 49-chapter curriculum covering core topics well. Good organization and clear descriptions. Adequate coverage of fundamentals, systems, and clinical aspects. However, missing some important areas: limited methodological depth, no chapters on scientific writing/communication, limited emerging trends coverage. Career chapter is brief. Some descriptions are very minimal. Solid but not as comprehensive as top models.

Model D presents a 51-chapter curriculum with good coverage of core topics. Notable inclusion of 'Neurociência Quântica' which is speculative and not mainstream. Some chapters like 'Iniciando na Neurociência' have odd titles for what should be career guidance. Good methodology coverage. Descriptions are adequately concise. Missing some clinical depth and emerging trends. Organization could be improved in places.

Model F provides a 41-chapter curriculum with good breadth but less depth than competitors. Chapters are well-titled and descriptions concise. However, coverage is somewhat superficial for mastery-level learning - many complex topics compressed into single chapters. Missing detailed methodology coverage, limited clinical content, and brief career guidance. Good structure but insufficient for PhD-level preparation.

Model N offers a 38-chapter curriculum that covers fundamentals well but lacks depth for advanced mastery. Good organization and clear descriptions. However, significantly missing: detailed methodology chapters, statistics/data analysis, computational neuroscience depth, many clinical applications, scientific writing, and comprehensive career guidance. Would work as an introductory course but insufficient for top 1% preparation.

Model L provides only 28 chapters, which is insufficient for the comprehensive mastery required. Missing many critical areas: foundational sciences, detailed sensory/motor systems, specific methodological training, many clinical topics, and scientific communication. Descriptions are appropriately concise but chapters are too broad (e.g., one chapter for all 'Sistemas Sensoriais'). Career chapter present but overall curriculum too superficial.

Model I has only 27 chapters, the smallest curriculum, making it clearly insufficient for mastery-level preparation. Very broad topics compressed into single chapters (e.g., 'Sistemas Sensoriais', 'Sistemas Motores'). Missing critical depth in methodology, statistics, clinical applications, and career development. Would serve as a basic introduction but fails to meet the requirement for comprehensive, PhD-level preparation. Descriptions are appropriately concise but content is too limited.

This model provides the most exceptional curriculum, perfectly aligned with the goal of taking a beginner to the top 1% of the field. It goes beyond standard biological topics to include essential skills for a modern leader in neuroscience, such as applied mathematics, scientific programming (Git, Python implied), data management (BIDS, NWB), grant writing, lab management, and entrepreneurship. The breakdown is granular and comprehensive, covering advanced techniques like optogenetics, transcriptomics, and deep learning with great specificity. The titles are concise and punchy, and the descriptions are dense with relevant keywords without fluff.

An outstanding output that rivals Model M in depth and breadth, offering over 100 chapters. It covers the foundational sciences (physics, chemistry, math) necessary for mastery and extends into high-level research topics and professional skills (ethics, reproducibility, career paths). It is slightly more encyclopedic in its listing style compared to the more curricular flow of Model M, but it is effectively perfect for the requirements.

A very strong curriculum that is well-balanced between biological foundations, clinical applications, and professional development. It explicitly includes chapters on leadership, mentoring, and grant writing, which are crucial for the 'complex projects' requirement. While excellent, it is less granular than M and K regarding the specific technical skills (like math and coding) required for the top 1%, grouping them into broader chapters.

This model offers a rigorous scientific curriculum with a strong emphasis on quantitative foundations (math, stats, physics), which is excellent for producing top-tier scientists. It covers a vast amount of ground. It scores slightly lower than the top three because it places a bit less emphasis on the 'leadership/management' aspect of the prompt compared to M and A, focusing more on the research technicalities.

A very comprehensive list (78 chapters) that covers the field well. It loses points for inefficiency in the clinical section, where it dedicates separate chapters to many individual diseases, which could have been grouped to allow more space for advanced technical methods or professional skills. However, the content quality is high.

A solid, detailed curriculum with 62 chapters. It covers all the necessary bases for a thorough education. It is ranked lower than the top tier because it feels more like a standard university syllabus rather than a specialized path to the 'top 1%', missing some of the explicit focus on advanced data science and leadership found in higher-ranked models.

A well-structured academic course with good progression. The descriptions are occasionally a bit wordier than necessary, but the content is accurate and covers the main pillars of neuroscience well. It lacks the unique advanced edge (startups, grants, deep tech) of the top models.

A good, standard curriculum. It covers the essential topics well but doesn't offer the exceptional depth or the specific focus on 'leading complex projects' that the prompt requested. The titles are also slightly more verbose than the ideal concise format.

A competent overview of the field, but with 40 chapters, it feels a bit lighter than the models scoring 8+. It covers the basics but lacks the deep dive into advanced methodology and professional skills needed for the 'mastery' requirement.
Adequate but basic. It covers the standard topics one would find in an undergraduate textbook but doesn't push the envelope towards the 'top 1%' or leadership level. The structure is sound but safe.

Similar to Model C, this is a standard undergraduate-level outline. It fails to include the advanced professional, computational, and leadership components explicitly requested to reach the top of the field.

While comprehensive in length, this model includes a chapter on 'Quantum Neuroscience' referencing microtubules, which is a controversial and largely speculative topic often associated with pseudoscience. In a rigorous scientific curriculum, this stands out as a potential quality issue unless framed very critically. Otherwise, the content is standard.

This output is far too brief (27 chapters) to fulfill the promise of teaching 'EVERYTHING' needed to be in the top 1%. It groups vast fields (like all neurological disorders) into single chapters, resulting in a superficial coverage.

Like Model I, this is too short and superficial for the specific requirements of the prompt. It acts more as a table of contents for a short introductory book rather than a comprehensive mastery course.

Cobertura extremamente completa e progressiva do zero ao nível avançado: fundamentos (física/química, biocelular, genética, bioquímica), sistemas e circuitos, métodos modernos (EEG/MEG, neuroimagem estrutural/funcional/molecular, neuromodulação, opto/quimiogenética, ômicas, organoides), estatística/causalidade/ML, ciência de dados, reprodutibilidade e ética. Mantém títulos concisos e sem vendors; inclui tendências atuais e prepara bem para pós-graduação e liderança em projetos complexos.

Muito bem estruturado para iniciantes com base forte (bioquímica, genética, física, estatística, método científico), segue para neuroanatomia/fisiologia/cognição e depois métodos e tópicos clínicos e computacionais (ômicas, organoides, ML, neuroengenharia, ética, gestão de dados). Boa progressão e atualização. Um pouco menos abrangente em gestão/liderança e translação clínica do que K.

Cobertura ampla e moderna, com bom bloco de métodos (eletrofisiologia, neuroimagem, neurofotônica, genética, organoides), computacional/ML, conectômica, BCI, neuromodulação, ciência aberta/reprodutibilidade, translacional/ensaios clínicos e liderança. Progressão é razoável, mas começa já em nível relativamente alto (menos “do zero” em fundamentos como química/física/estatística básica) e há pequenos deslizes de linguagem (“rodent”).

Currículo de nível muito avançado e abrangente, especialmente em métodos (spike sorting, fMRI análise, microscopia, multiômicas, VR/AR, closed-loop, HPC) e clínica/translação/regulação. Excelente para formar top-tier e pesquisa. Porém peca em concisão de alguns títulos (ex.: “fMRI: princípios e pré-processamento”) e tem erro (“Apodose” em desenvolvimento), além de a extensão e granularidade poderem ser excessivas para um “capítulo” típico.

Sólido e bem organizado, com forte base (bioquímica, genética, biofísica), sistemas, métodos modernos (neuroimagem, registros invasivos/não invasivos, estimulação, métodos moleculares, análise/ML) e tópicos avançados (neurotecnologia, terapias avançadas, big neuroimagem, filosofia). Boa progressão e atualização. Menos conteúdo explícito de gestão de dados/reprodutibilidade/ciência aberta e liderança em comparação aos melhores.

Muito completo em neurociência cognitiva e temas contemporâneos (consciência, filosofia, neuroética, IA), inclui métodos e gestão de projetos/leitura crítica/redação. Boa progressão. Pontos fracos: alguns títulos longos e há um capítulo com parêntese no título (“Neurociência aplicada a negócios e marketing (com responsabilidade)”), que foge da diretriz de títulos diretos/sem adornos; também há certa dispersão para aplicações (neuromarketing/direito) antes de consolidar alguns pilares de translação e reprodutibilidade em profundidade.

Cobertura extensa (muito clínica e de sistemas), inclui múltiplas áreas especializadas e métodos. Porém tende a fragmentar doenças em muitos capítulos e fica menos equilibrado em fundamentos quantitativos (estatística/ML/gestão de dados/reprodutibilidade aparecem pouco). Ainda assim é robusto e bem em PT-BR.

Abrangente e inclui tendências (IA, CRISPR, etc.), mas contém um capítulo problemático (“Neurociência Quântica” com ‘especulações’), o que reduz rigor e alinhamento com preparação acadêmica séria. Alguns títulos ficam menos concisos (“Interfaces Neuropróteses”) e há erros/acentuação (“alostericas”). Cobertura de métodos quantitativos e reprodutibilidade é moderada.

Boa cobertura e progressão para um curso geral, inclui tópicos modernos (microbiota-eixo intestino-cérebro, sistema glinfático, teorias preditivas, ciência aberta). Contudo, descrições e títulos têm mais “filler” e são mais longos/explicativos do que o pedido. Menos profundidade em estatística/causalidade/gestão de dados e liderança para chegar ao nível de comandar projetos muito complexos.

Estrutura coerente e relativamente moderna, mas é genérico: muitos capítulos são amplos demais, com pouca especificidade metodológica/quantitativa e pouca preparação explícita para pesquisa avançada (reprodutibilidade, causalidade, pipelines, ensaios clínicos). Adequado como visão geral, insuficiente para “topo 1%”.

Boa base de neurofisiologia/sistemas e alguns métodos, porém falta um eixo forte de metodologia científica moderna (desenho experimental, estatística, reprodutibilidade, gestão de dados), além de pouca preparação para liderança e pesquisa de ponta. Escopo mais próximo de graduação tradicional.

Currículo clássico, razoavelmente completo em sistemas e alguns métodos, mas menos atualizado e menos profundo em ferramentas modernas (ômicas, ciência de dados/ML, padrões de reprodutibilidade, gestão de dados, translação/ensaios). Não atende bem à exigência de preparar para projetos muito complexos e certificações avançadas.

Muito resumido para as expectativas: poucos capítulos para cobrir um campo enorme; falta profundidade em métodos modernos, estatística/ML, reprodutibilidade, translacionalidade e liderança. Títulos e descrições são ok, mas o conteúdo não chega perto de ‘mastery’.

Conteúdo básico e curto, com cobertura superficial e pouca atualização/detalhe metodológico. Quase não há reprodutibilidade, desenho experimental avançado, gestão de dados, causalidade, translação clínica estruturada ou liderança. Fica distante das metas de excelência e preparo para pós-graduação avançada.
